ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the systematic approach to engineering small computers that can perform different tasks.
I learned how to create circuits and build computers. Very well taught course.

A very thorough introduction to the the computer engineering world. From basic logic gates to more complicated state diagrams and truth tables, the course made sure to cover the necessary basics of digital systems.
Gates and circuits, latches and flip-flops, K-maps, (de)multiplexers and en/decoders, adders and registers.
I learned the basics of logic circuits.

I learned about boolean logic, various combinational and sequential circuits, circuit timings, and how these can be designed using state machines and state tables. This course introduced me to Multisim which we used to simulate many of the circuits during our lab sessions.

I learned about digital design by first understanding binary, octal, and hexa-decimal number systems. Later in the course, we covered logic gates and Kavanaugh maps to reduce logic gate implementation. We covered lathces and flip-flops and registers as well.
Combinational and sequential digital design.
I definitely felt as though my computer engineering skills, multisim ability, logic and understanding of simple computers improved
basics of computer engineering
Basic combination/sequential logic circuit design and analysis, as well as some basic Boolean algebra.
Learning to integrate and implement different logic components through lab simulations and assignments.
I learned about binary math, circuit design, gates, combinational logic, etc.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: not too harsh on the homework, labs are interesting, lecture content is good 
Weaknesses: lecture material was taught at a fast pace

This course was very well taught, however, the workload was extremely high since we met twice a week for lecture and once for lab. Having a pset due every other week was helpful, but it was still overwhelming. The lab should be offered as an extra half a credit, as done with physics, chem and other courses.

The course's workload was never overwhelming, and Professor Panda was very open to student input when it came to extending deadlines or offering more accessible lab hours. A weakness of the course would be the lack of homework or lab solutions. For the most part I had to turn to outside resources to test how well I was understanding the material.
The course gives a solid introduction to circuit design principles. The main weakness for this course is it takes very long to receive feedback on past psets and labs.

Strengths: the content is organized in a logical manner.
Weaknesses: the lectures were slow at times; labs sometimes felt repetitive (but this will probably be better in-person with actual hands-on circuit building instead of simulations).

I thought this course was exciting and engaging throughout the first half, but by the end I'd lost interest in the subject. The assignments were extremely tedious - both the labs and psets sometimes felt more punitive than enriching.

I felt that the course was a bit inconsistent with its practices. For example, the course started off strong by having a solid outline of what we were going to be learning, but as we reached the later parts of the course, there was less structure and seeking outside resources was almost required. The textbook is a bit hard to navigate and being given sections to read was helpful for the first few weeks.
I enjoyed how the assignments provide opportunities to use what we learned in class to create circuits/machines that has actual function, such as parity checkers and up counters.
The course was well-taught and the labs were a greate addition to the course material. The material was engaging and had many applications for future classes.

As much as we students dont want more homework, this course could really benefit from pre-lab assignments. So many labs had to be extended this semester, and I feel like it prevented the staff from doing something that they really wanted to do, which was the processor design assignment.
Not much room for engagement
she is a very good professor who will take time to thoroughly explain things to you. Labs were kind of messy and tedious

The lecture notes were pretty helpful and overall very understandable. Assignments/labs were sometimes a lot of busy work but not hard work, which wasn't super helpful. Grades also took a very long time to receive, so it was sometimes hard to tell how well you were understanding the material.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Overall, this class was very successful remote. Everything was online, so there were no issues with being remote.
The independent labs were a good opportunity to take my time and learn the material, so I enjoyed that switch over to Multisim.
I think for a virtual class it would be better to have more problem sets and fewer (virtual) labs.
Recorded lectures were extremely helpful for reviewing concepts that may not have been clear.
Maybe more question asking
It was a fine course

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, because it was extremely helpful for people pursuing engineering, and I feel like I have a great understanding of the material.
Yes. Professor Panda's lectures were clear and had thorough examples. The material covered also seems essential to upper level classes.
I wouldn't recommend if it's virtual, doing simulations for the labs really took away from the experience.

If you want to learn about computer engineering without wasting hours and hours on labs, take CS201. You'll learn the most important 70-80% of the material from this class without all of the busywork. If you're thinking of majoring in EE, you could take it as a way to test the waters (that's what I did, and I realized that EE is not for me).
Yes, the concepts are interesting enough to keep you engaged. Even without a background in electronics, this course provides a good introduction to design of machines.
I would recommend this class to another student. It was well taught and gave a great primer in digital electronics moving forward.
I would as it was still interesting and the exams were fair in my opinion
Yes she is a very good professor, but the TAs are not the best and dont do a great job of explaining things to you. There are not that many assignments and assessments were not difficult

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded Lecture

There was 2 live virtual lectures every week, but Professor Panda made sure to record every session and upload to Media Library. There was also lab sections that were live, but for the most part the labs were completed independently and lab sections were used for help.
Live lectures were recorded, there were also weekly lab sessions.
N/A
Virtual lab
Virtual Labs
Virtual Lecture
virtual labs
Sometimes watched lectures live
